author: By Campbell Robertson
title: With Watchful Eyes, a Nationwide Network Tracks Antisemitic Threats
description: The mass shooting at the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh led to arguably the most ambitious effort ever undertaken to protect Jewish institutions in America.
content: In a dimly lit conference room on an upper floor of a Chicago mid-rise, an intricately detailed snapshot of American peril is being taken, minute by unsettling minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Alan Menken on ‘The Little Mermaid’ and the Mixed Blessing of Disney Fame
description: The composer talked revisiting “The Little Mermaid” after nearly 35 years and the similarities between working with Howard Ashman and Lin-Manuel Miranda.
content: Alan Menken composed the musical versions of “Little Shop of Horrors” and “A Bronx Tale,” but he is at peace with being known as a Disney composer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in California
description: A 1928 home with separate guest quarters in Los Angeles, a Colonial Revival house in Stockton and a Craftsman bungalow Oakland.
content: This house is in Mount Washington, a neighborhood in the northeastern part of the city known for its hilly streets and sweeping views of downtown Los Angeles. It is not far from the hiking trails and picnic areas at Ernest E. Debs Regional Park and Audubon Center at Debs Park. It is also close to Heritage Square Museum, a collection of Victorian-era buildings focused on life in 19th-century Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Murphy
title: The Supreme Court Is Crippling Environmental Protections. Where Is Congress?
description: Will lawmakers allow what one justice called the court’s “appointment of itself as the national decision maker on environmental policy”?
content: In 1965, President Lyndon Johnson told a room full of governors and state officials that he found the filthy river flowing a mile from the Capitol “disgraceful.” Now the Potomac River runs much cleaner, thanks to the landmark Clean Water Act of 1972 — and that adjective employed by Johnson serves as an apt description today of the failures of the Supreme Court and Congress to protect the nation’s waterways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
title: New Details in Debt Limit Deal: Where $136 Billion in Cuts Will Come From
description: Two years of spending caps, additional work requirements for food stamps and cuts to I.R.S. funding are among the components in the deal.
content: The full legislative text of Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s agreement in principle with President Biden to suspend the nation’s borrowing limit revealed new and important details about the deal, which House lawmakers are expected to vote on this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: In Third Place but Armed for a Run at the Top
description: The Yankees held steady as their starting rotation got healthy. With Luis Severino back, and Carlos Rodón on the way, there is reason to expect brighter days ahead.
content: Luis Severino was in a playful mood late Saturday afternoon at Yankee Stadium. The day had gone so well that he mused about pitching only in the sunshine. He felt so strong that he guessed he could throw his fastball 103 miles per hour. He was dressed for success, and he knew it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Sudan’s War ‘Robbed Us of Our Art and Our Peace’
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 29, 2023.
content: “The artistic, creative ecosystem is going to be broken for a while.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Series Finale Recap: The Dotted Line
description: Who won? Who lost? Who was left staring off into the sea?
content: Whenever a show as talked-about and admired as “Succession” reaches its end, fans and critics start coming up with lists of the biggest questions that still “need to be answered” in the finale. More often than not, the finale itself answers some of those questions but leaves others dangling, because the stories TV creators want to tell do not always line up with what the viewers expect. And that’s fine. That’s entertainment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Will Erdogan’s Victory Soften Turkey’s Opposition to Sweden in NATO?
description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, re-elected as Turkey’s president, is expected to toughen up at home but seek better ties with Washington and ratify Swedish membership of the military alliance.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, invoking themes of Turkish nationalism and counterterrorism, has been the main obstacle toward Sweden joining the NATO alliance after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Uganda Enacts an Anti-Gay Law
description: Also, a rare daytime assault on Kyiv.
content: The president of Uganda signed a punitive anti-gay bill yesterday that includes the death penalty as a punishment, enshrining into law an intensifying crackdown on L.G.B.T.Q. people in the conservative East African nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans and Ken Bensinger
title: A Small Town’s Tragedy, Distorted by Trump’s Megaphone
description: When a teen’s killing became a right-wing talking point, the rush to outrage obscured a more complicated story.
content: There were no known witnesses when Shannon Brandt and Cayler Ellingson got into an argument in the blurry hours after last call at Buck’s n Doe’s Bar & Grill in September. And no one but Mr. Brandt could say with certainty what led him to run over Mr. Ellingson with his Ford Explorer, crushing him to death in a gravel alley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Cathay Pacific Fights to Emerge From the Long Shadow of Covid
description: Pandemic lockdowns, on the heels of the turmoil of pro-democracy protests, hurt an airline that relied on Hong Kong as a vibrant gateway to Asia.
content: Few major airlines in the world were hit by the Covid pandemic as hard as Cathay Pacific, the flagship carrier of Hong Kong, or have labored so mightily to recover from it. Its business was decimated by some of the industry’s most expansive flight bans and quarantine requirements. And the pandemic wasn’t the start of Cathay’s troubles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: Texas Lawmakers Pass Ban on D.E.I. Programs at State Universities
description: It’s the latest state to defund diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives.
content: The News: Just a day before the Texas legislative session ended, state lawmakers approved a ban on offices and programs that promote diversity, equity and inclusion at publicly funded colleges and universities. On Sunday, both chambers approved Senate Bill 17, which was sponsored by Brandon Creighton, a Republican state senator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Rosenfield
title: Rosalind Franklin’s Role in DNA Discovery, Once Ignored, Is Told Anew in Song
description: “Double Helix,” at Bay Street Theater, illuminates the British scientist’s contributions, which became the basis for James Watson and Francis Crick’s 1953 breakthrough.
content: During the summer of 2020, the composer and lyricist Madeline Myers spent hours at the piano in her Manhattan apartment as she struggled to write three songs for her new musical, “Double Helix,” about the British chemist Rosalind Franklin. The challenge wasn’t strictly about marrying words to a score, but conveying the science of a crucial moment in the discovery of DNA’s structure — and making the songs entertaining.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Liam Stack
title: With Mpox at Risk of Flaring, Health Officials Advise, ‘Get Vaccinated’
description: Cases dropped after a successful public health campaign last summer. But the disease still has a low-level presence in the city, and many people remain at risk.
content: Late last year, with cases at a trickle, New York City wound down its mpox emergency response. Health officials stopped posting updates about cases. Vaccination vans stopped appearing outside nightclubs. The number of people being vaccinated against the disease flatlined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: China Announces Plan to Land Astronauts on Moon by 2030
description: The announcement formalized a timeline that Chinese scientists have set out before, as the United States and China ramp up competition in space.
content: China plans to complete a mission to land a person on the moon by 2030, a government official announced on Monday, in the highest-level confirmation of China’s ambitions for a crewed lunar landing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: The United Arab Emirates Is Heading for the Asteroid Belt
description: After a successful mission to Mars, the Emirati space agency is planning a tour of the debris field between Mars and Jupiter, with a focus on one of its most intriguing objects.
content: Building off the success of its Hope spacecraft, which is still circling and studying Mars, the United Arab Emirates announced on Monday plans for an ambitious follow-up mission: a grand tour of the asteroid belt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: ‘Succession’ Clears the Air: Here’s What to Read
description: Still sorting through the finale? Here’s a broad range of hard and soft takes to help you out.
content: This article includes spoilers for the series finale of “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Miss ‘Succession’ Already? Here’s What to Watch Next
description: Now that the Roys have shuffled offstage, where can bereft fans turn for their regular dose of acid insults and privileged misery? We have a few ideas.
content: The end of “Succession” leaves a Waystar Royco-sized hole in our hearts. With the various Roys scattered, licking their wounds, where can bereft fans turn for their regular dose of acid insults, soapy skulduggery and privileged misery grounded by occasional glimpses of human vulnerability and warmth? We have a few ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: Laying ‘Succession’ to Rest: Pain Sponges, Heels of Bread and Eldest Boys
description: As HBO’s hit series comes to a close, was everything foretold in Episode 1?
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers and exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Alberta’s Vote Will Test American-Style Far-Right Politics
description: An election in Alberta will be a test of a premier who has said that she models her politics after those of prominent right-wing U.S. politicians.
content: Voters in Alberta, the epicenter of conservative politics in Canada, will select a new provincial government on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Hockey Championship the U.S. Men Just Can’t Seem to Win
description: American men have achieved thrilling victories at the Olympics, but they haven’t won a world hockey championship in decades.
content: After a strong start, the U.S. men’s hockey team was disappointingly eliminated from the world championship over the weekend. Again.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Month 29, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 29, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Debt Ceiling Deal Includes New Work Requirements for Food Stamps
description: The agreement will place additional work requirements on older Americans to receive food assistance, but will remove those barriers for veterans and homeless adults.
content: One of the most contentious issues surrounding talks over raising the debt limit has been whether the Biden administration would agree to stricter work requirements for people seeking food stamps and other safety net assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: A Climactic Opening
description: Floods, landslides and fires are making it harder to get national parks ready for summer.
content: Today is something of a curtain raiser for the U.S. National Parks system, ushering in its busiest season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Barkan
title: Trump Will Be Tough to Beat, if 1968 Is Any Guide
description: Let’s think back to Nixon versus Reagan.
content: Ron DeSantis, the 44-year-old governor of Florida, has entered the presidential race, establishing himself as the most formidable Republican rival to Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: I’ve Spent 28 Years Pondering the Wild World of My Home
description: The more I learn about the creatures with whom I share this ecosystem, the more I understand how much I do not understand.
content: NASHVILLE — Though it is still more than three weeks from the summer solstice, Memorial Day is the unofficial first day of summer, and already it is hot here. Every day now, temperatures rise well into the 80s, sometimes as high as 90 degrees. At both a global and a local level, the life-obliterating fallout of excessive heat becomes clearer with every passing summer, but this is a wonderful, old-timey kind of summertime heat: soft and damp and breathing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Andersen
title: ‘Succession’ Nailed the Unreal Way We Live Now
description: The show captured the terrifying, mesmerizing interplay between fact and fiction and turned it into great television.
content: Like most of the great cable dramas, and to me, like so much of contemporary life, “Succession” was simultaneously tragic and comic, entertaining and horrifying. Over its four seasons, which had a grand 90-minute finale on Sunday night, it was the apotheosis of a line of dark, galvanizing, breathtakingly excellent cable dramas about a criminal-adjacent milieu, shows that also have important, big things to say about our greed-addled American reality — “The Sopranos,” “The Wire” and “Breaking Bad.” But “Succession” did something that none of its predecessors did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In Cold War Berlin, an Affair Born of Chaos and Control
description: Jenny Erpenbeck’s novel “Kairos” folds intimations of German history and cultural memory into a torrid romance.
content: The first thing to know about Jenny Erpenbeck’s new novel, “Kairos,” is that it’s a wallow. I was in the mood for one. It’s a cathartic leak of a novel, a beautiful bummer, and the floodgates open early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani
title: Afghan Women Who Aided U.S. Military Wait for Asylum in America
description: Members of the Afghan Army’s all-female platoon are some of the roughly 70,000 Afghans living in the United States whose temporary status has left them with an uncertain future.
content: It was almost 3 a.m. in New York, but Nazdana Hassani refused to fall asleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Downey
title: In Tokyo, Skipping the Hot and New for Enduring Haunts
description: Using a guidebook published more than 20 years ago, a writer searches out the bars and restaurants that express the city’s traditional eating and drinking culture.
content: Upon landing in Tokyo in December, three years since my last visit, I thought about where I should first eat and drink in this vast, wondrous city. The answer was obvious: Iseto, an ancient sake-drinking den operating in the same wooden house since 1948.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Jason Horowitz
title: Spanish Prime Minister Calls Snap Election for July
description: Pedro Sánchez, who leads a fragile coalition government, made the announcement after his liberal party lost ground to conservatives in regional and local elections over the weekend.
content: Spain’s prime minister, Pedro Sánchez, said Monday that he would dissolve Parliament and called a snap election for July after his liberal party suffered bruising defeats in regional and local elections over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Mitchell
title: The Real Reason Your Groceries Are Getting So Expensive
description: Grocery-retailer consolidation is damaging our food system, stifling innovation and making everything more expensive.
content: Food Fresh is the only grocery store in a rural stretch of southeastern Georgia. It has many five-star Google reviews praising its freshly butchered meats, tomato bar and friendly service. Yet it faces a threat to its survival that no amount of management skill can overcome. Big retailers like Walmart and Kroger “have a handle on suppliers that I can’t touch,” said Food Fresh’s owner, Michael Gay. The chains wrest deep discounts from suppliers, making it impossible for the store to come close to matching the chains’ prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Overcrowded India? This State Is Desperate for More Babies.
description: India will soon be history’s most populous country. But the growth is uneven, and the Himalayan state of Sikkim is offering cash incentives to encourage births.
content: Sikkim, nestled in the Himalayas and surrounded on three sides by Nepal, Bhutan and Tibet, stands out in the teeming diversity of India’s states. It has the country’s tallest peak. It is the world’s largest producer of smoky black cardamom. It also has India’s smallest population, not even three-quarters of a million people, and its lowest birthrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Succession’ Is Over. Why Did We Care?
description: For five years, the series and the question of who would end up in charge captivated a chatty swath of the TV audience. But did anyone really win in the end?
content: This article includes spoilers for the series finale of “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Will Ripped Jeans Ever Go Out of Style?
description: A reader asks how to learn to live with distressed denim, a trend that shows no sign of letting up.
content: According to Glenn Martens, the creative director of Diesel, when Renzo Rosso, the brand’s founder, introduced distressed denim back in the 1980s — “distressed” meaning ripped, faded and otherwise made to look old, even though the jeans were actually new — he sent a box of his products to retailers in Japan. The retailers sent the jeans back. They thought he had made a mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Beaugez
title: Club Ebony, a Historic Blues Venue Tied to B.B. King, Rises Again
description: The Indianola, Miss., club was part of the chitlin circuit, where Black performers found refuge during the Jim Crow era. After urgent renovations, it will reopen this week.
content: Club Ebony, a famed blues venue in Indianola, Miss., that was part of the chitlin circuit — a loose network of Black-owned clubs and venues in segregated American cities — has hosted hundreds of memorable moments. Bobby Rush, the 89-year-old blues singer, recalled one of his favorites in a recent interview: a scene from B.B. King’s 2014 homecoming concert.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Mystery of the Disappearing van Gogh
description: After a painting by the Dutch artist sold at auction, a movie producer claimed to be the owner. It later vanished from sight, with a trail leading to Caribbean tax havens and a jailed Chinese billionaire.
content: The bidding for Lot 17 started at $23 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: This Town Made Tina Turner. She Made It Famous.
description: The singer, who just died, immortalized her hometown in a song. Its residents remember how she sprinkled her glitter onto Nutbush, Tenn., opening it to the world.
content: Reaching Nutbush, a speck of a Tennessee town between Memphis and Nashville, requires exiting Interstate 40, just after the tourism billboard plastered with Tina Turner’s photo, passing the Tina Turner Museum and driving up the Tina Turner Highway, which leads to the town’s sign declaring it the “Birthplace of Tina Turner.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anderson Tepper
title: A Provocative Satirist Left a Pervasive Legacy, Influencing African Writing
description: Binyavanga Wainaina attacked insulting clichés in the essay, “How to Write About Africa,” in 2005. In a posthumous collection of the same name, his range as a writer is on display.
content: The Kenyan writer Binyavanga Wainaina was many things in his short, frenetic life: memoirist and roving essayist, trailblazing editor and publisher, agitator and activist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Aggeler
title: How to Get Absolutely No Sun This Summer
description: None! Don’t even think about it!
content: Roughly 4.6 billion years ago, a gigantic cloud of gas collapsed in on itself, crumpling under the weight of its own gravity, and became what we call “the sun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Erdogan’s victory in Turkey.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey beat the opposition candidate Kemal Kilicdaroglu in a runoff yesterday with 52.1 percent of the vote, according to Turkey’s Supreme Election Council, assuring the mercurial leader another five years in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Sarah Goldberg on the ‘Barry’ Finale and Bad Decisions
description: ‘It was definitely a comedy when we started,” the actress said. But in the end, it “was a morality tale” about the choices that make us who we are.
content: “I signed up for a comedy,” the actress Sarah Goldberg said of her role in “Barry.” “I never thought I’d have to cry so much in a comedy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: In the ‘Barry’ Finale, Hollywood Gets Away with Murder
description: Bill Hader’s dark comedy made the culture of violence and the culture of showbiz into collaborators.
content: This article includes spoilers for the “Barry” series finale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Should Some Criminal Records Be Wiped Clean After 7 Years?
description: Lawmakers in New York may pass the Clean Slate Act, which would seal criminal records for those who finish their sentences and stay out of trouble for several years.
content: Melinda Agnew has done a lot in the 25 years since she got in trouble with the law: She earned an associate degree, followed by a bachelor’s and a master’s. She had three children and recently became a grandmother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Women’s Tennis Suddenly Has a Big(ish) Three
description: Iga Swiatek, Elena Rybakina and Aryna Sabalenka have been winning just about everything important lately, emerging as a potential triumvirate unseen in the women’s game for about a decade.
content: Iga Swiatek, Elena Rybakina and Aryna Sabalenka have won a combined five Grand Slam singles titles. Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic have won 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu and Andy Newman
title: After Death of Girl, 6, Mother Faces Charges Over Surviving Children
description: Jalayah Eason was found bruised and unconscious in the Bronx. Her mother has been charged with endangering the welfare of her surviving son and daughter.
content: The mother of a 6-year-old girl who died Friday after the police found her bruised and unconscious in a Bronx apartment has been charged with endangering the welfare of her two surviving children, the police said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Miami Heat Are on the Brink of Bad History
description: No N.B.A. team has lost a best-of-seven playoff series after winning the first three games, but the Heat are one loss from being the first.
content: When a team takes a three-games-to-none lead in a best-of-seven series, it is time to start looking ahead to the next round or to a championship parade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Why Spending Cuts Likely Won’t Shake the Economy
description: With low unemployment and above-trend inflation, the economy is well positioned to absorb the modest budget cuts that President Biden and Republicans negotiated.
content: The last time the United States came perilously close to defaulting on its debt, a Democratic president and a Republican speaker of the House cut a deal to raise the nation’s borrowing limit and tightly restrain some federal spending growth for years to come. The deal averted default, but it hindered what was already a slow recovery from the Great Recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman
title: An Influencer With a Mission: Supporting New York Restaurants
description: For Jaeki Cho’s Righteous Eats, food is the hook, but the social media series is really a platform to celebrate the people who make up one of the world’s most diverse cities.
content: More Than Likes is a series about social media personalities trying to do positive things for their communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Elite High School’s Admissions Plan May Face Supreme Court Test
description: The justices will soon rule on race-conscious admissions plans at Harvard and U.N.C. A new appeals court case asks whether schools can use race-neutral tools to achieve racial diversity.
content: In the coming weeks, the Supreme Court is very likely to forbid colleges and universities to use race as a factor in admissions decisions. Indeed, when the cases challenging the admissions programs at Harvard and the University of North Carolina were argued in October, some justices were already looking at the next question on the horizon: whether admissions officers may promote racial diversity by using race-neutral criteria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: In ‘Succession,’ Tom and Greg Were Never Playing the Long Game
description: In a joint interview Monday morning, Matthew Macfadyen and Nicholas Braun reflected on their characters’ bond and their big finale slap fight. “It was real,” Macfadyen said.
content: Sadomasochistic. Abusive. Codependent. These might all describe the deranged bromance between Tom Wambsgans, the cornfed basic, and Greg Hirsch, the leggy princeling of ATN, in “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Saffitz
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Idol’ and ‘Dave’
description: HBO premieres its new series from the creator of “Euphoria,” and the show starring Lil Dicky wraps up.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 29 — June 4. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Congrats, You Made the French Open. You Get to Play Djokovic and Alcaraz.
description: Little-known players learned humbling lessons when they drew Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic in the first round of the French Open.
content: Aleksandar Kovacevic did plenty of tossing and turning Sunday night before finally settling in for what he thought was about six hours of restless sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of May 22, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Natalia Yermak
title: Russian Missile and Drone Attacks on Kyiv Send Civilians Racing for Cover
description: A drone attack on Tuesday came after a barrage of missiles on Monday sent schoolchildren running for shelter as explosions echoed across the Ukrainian capital, rare daytime aerial assaults on the city.
content: Even in a city where people have adapted the routines of ordinary life to wartime, a drone attack on the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv, on Tuesday, after a barrage of missiles the day before, was a reminder that while the fighting has been concentrated hundreds of miles east, the city still has a Russian bull’s-eye on it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Getting Screened Early for Breast Cancer
description: Readers respond to the new breast cancer screening guidelines. Also: Outdoor dining in New York; employee “belonging”; swimmable urban waters.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Five Takeaways From Turkey’s Presidential Election
description: Crises including earthquakes and inflation did not stop the re-election of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The vote was seen as free but not fair, as he used his power to tilt the playing field.
content: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s re-election grants him five more years to deepen his conservative imprint on Turkish society and to realize his ambition of increasing the country’s economic and geopolitical power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman and Sasha Arutyunova
title: Guitar Making as a Life’s Work
description: “To somebody else, it’s just some wood glued together,” Freeman Vines, 80, said. “To me, it’s something else.”
content: Art of Craft is a series about specialists whose work rises to the level of art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A van Gogh Still Life and a Head-Spinning Rabbit Hole
description: To learn about a vanished painting by the famous Dutch artist, a team of Times journalists combed through thousands of pages of documents — and knocked on some doors.
content: Michael Forsythe, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, is used to spending hours poring over documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: She Said Her Professor Sexually Harassed Her. His Wife Won Damages.
description: A case involving a graduate student and her art history professor illustrates the tangled state of sexual power dynamics in Japan.
content: The prominent art history professor and his student had finished dinner and were strolling along the river in Kyoto, Japan’s picturesque former capital, when they stopped at a bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Ugandan President Signs Anti-Gay Law That Includes Death Penalty as a Punishment
description: The legislation is among the most restrictive of its kind in the world and was condemned by Western leaders and the United Nations human rights body.
content: The president of Uganda signed a punitive anti-gay bill on Monday that includes the death penalty, enshrining into law an intensifying crackdown against L.G.B.T.Q. people in the conservative East African nation and dismissing widespread calls not to impose one of the world’s most restrictive anti-gay measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: 8 People Rescued in Partial Building Collapse in Iowa
description: There were no deaths reported but more than a dozen people were escorted out of the apartment building in Davenport and eight rescued. The cause of the collapse was not immediately clear.
content: A search and rescue effort was winding down in Iowa on Monday after the partial collapse of a six-story apartment building the day before, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Ukraine Sees New Virtue in Wind Power: It’s Harder to Destroy
description: Bombarding the power grid has been an essential part of Russia’s invasion, but officials say it would take many more missile strikes to badly damage a wind farm than a power plant.
content: ODESA, Ukraine — The giants catch the wind with their huge arms, helping to keep the lights on in Ukraine — newly built windmills on plains along the Black Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Let Peak Produce Do the Heavy Lifting
description: Whole roasted red peppers are a vibrant meatless main, and tender lettuces are tossed in an onion-dip dressing.
content: Memorial Day weekend, the unofficial start of summer, kicks off the official season of laid-back feasting. Whether it’s a simple weeknight dinner or a weekend blowout with friends, summer dining demands easy recipes, or at least ones that don’t require hours in the kitchen when it’s sunny outside. Good thing the season’s bounty of bold, vivid produce makes even low-prep meals feel extra deluxe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Standing (and Dancing) Strong at New York City Ballet
description: A flurry of debuts. The return of Sara Mearns. Performances that lingered after the curtain fell. Here are the highlights from a packed spring season.
content: If New York City Ballet’s spring season could be bottled into a fragrance, it would be fresh and green, with the earthy, sweet scent of a breeze after a bout of rain. How did we get here? The company, seemingly all of a sudden, looks so strong, and more important, so light. The high fives passed from one dancer to the next as they crossed the stage in Alexei Ratmansky’s “Namouna” seemed more funny, more victorious and more true than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Impossible Math of the Debt Deal’s Detractors
description: If you can’t cut big costs and you won’t raise revenue, there’s only so much balancing you can do.
content: Members of the ultraconservative House Freedom Caucus are unhappy that the debt ceiling deal wouldn’t significantly reduce federal budget deficits in coming years. One referred to the deal as a sandwich made of excrement, another called it “insanity,” and a third tweeted a barfing emoji. Classy stuff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Who Was Bill Wambsganss, and Was He a ‘Succession’ Spoiler?
description: In the HBO series finale, Tom Wambsgans beat out three competitors at once, just like the Cleveland second baseman who turned the only unassisted triple play in World Series history.
content: When Tom Wambsgans outmaneuvered the Roy siblings, getting himself named as the U.S. executive running Waystar Royco for GoJo at the end of a rollicking finale of the HBO series “Succession,” it likely came as a shock to many of the viewers at home. But to fans of baseball’s early days, and internet conspiracy theorists, the signs were there for Tom to come out on top, besting three competitors at the same time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Seo
title: How a Cardiologist Keeps His Heart Healthy
description: We asked Dr. Hugh Calkins, a cardiologist at Johns Hopkins Medicine, for his best heart health tips.
content: We asked Dr. Hugh Calkins, a cardiologist at Johns Hopkins Medicine, for his best heart health tips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Apartment Building in Iowa Partially Collapses
description: Emergency medical workers escorted more than a dozen people out of the six-story building and rescued eight others. No deaths were reported.
content: Emergency medical workers escorted more than a dozen people out of the six-story building and rescued eight others. No deaths were reported.
source.name: The New York Times
